title: Trusting Natural Well-Being: Mia’s Bright New Start
summary: Trusting her child’s natural well-being, Angela shifts into alignment—asking “What excites you?” instead of worrying. On day one at her new school, Mia effortlessly attracts two new friends. A real-life spark of Abraham-Hicks’ Law of Attraction in parenting.
story:
Angela Martinez, a 35-year-old Project Manager at a bustling tech startup in Santa Monica, leans back in her kitchen chair one Tuesday evening and watches her seven-year-old daughter, Mia, fidget with crayons at the little table by the window. Mia is starting second grade next week at a new school in Echo Park, and tonight she’s worrying about making friends. As a parent, Angela feels the tug of anxiety too—but she remembers something she recently learned from Abraham-Hicks: “Trust their natural well-being.”

Across from her sits Daniel Carter, Angela’s husband and a 36-year-old architect, quietly sipping his green tea. He smiles at Angela. “You know,” he says, “she always figures things out.” Angela takes a slow breath and nods. Instead of jumping in with solutions—“Don’t worry, honey, you’ll be fine”—she gently asks Mia, “What’s one exciting thing you’d like about your new classroom?” Mia’s eyes brighten as she imagines a bright yellow reading corner and group art projects.

Over the next few days, Angela practices focusing on her daughter’s natural resilience rather than her fears. On the drive to school, she chats with Mia about her favorite storybooks and reminds herself that life inherently supports well-being. She lets go of the urge to control every detail—the seating chart, recess buddy assignments, lunch menu—and simply affirms, “I trust that you’re guided toward friends who love having you around.”

On Mia’s first morning, the little girl bounds off the bus with a grin that stretches ear to ear. She’s made two new pals already—one who loves dinosaurs as much as she does, another who shares her passion for mermaids. At the dinner table, Mia excitedly sketches a plan for tomorrow’s art project. Angela catches Daniel’s eye, and they share a satisfied glance. By trusting their daughter’s natural well-being—and releasing the need to micromanage—they’ve watched her thrive exactly as she was meant to.
